name: Feng Zhang
summary: Feng Zhang is a Chinese-American biomedical engineer who was one of the first to adapt the CRISPR-Cas9 system for genome editing in eukaryotic cells. His 2013 paper demonstrated CRISPR could edit human and mouse cells, launching a revolution in genetic engineering. He also developed the CRISPR-based diagnostic tool SHERLOCK for detecting viral infections.
timeline: Published first CRISPR editing in human cells
Developed smaller Cas12 and Cas13 systems

name: Katalin Kariko
summary: Katalin Karikó is a Hungarian-American biochemist who pioneered the use of modified messenger RNA (mRNA) for therapeutic purposes. Her decades-long research, often dismissed and unfunded, proved that chemically modified mRNA could be used safely in the body. This breakthrough enabled the rapid development of COVID-19 mRNA vaccines by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna, saving millions of lives.
timeline: Published key paper on modified nucleosides with Weissman
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Drew Weissman
summary: Drew Weissman is an American immunologist who, together with Katalin Karikó, discovered that modifying nucleosides in mRNA prevents it from triggering an inflammatory immune response. This discovery was crucial for making mRNA therapeutics viable and enabled the COVID-19 mRNA vaccines. He shared the 2023 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.
timeline: Co-published mRNA modification discovery with Karikó
Demonstrated modified mRNA increases protein production
mRNA vaccine technology used for COVID-19
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: David Baker
summary: David Baker is an American biochemist who developed Rosetta, a software suite for protein structure prediction and design. His lab designed entirely new proteins that don't exist in nature, opening the field of computational protein design. He shared the 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for computational protein design.

name: George Church
summary: George Church is an American geneticist who pioneered the development of multiple genomic technologies including next-generation DNA sequencing, CRISPR gene editing applications, and synthetic biology. He initiated the Human Genome Project and Personal Genome Project. His lab has advanced gene drive technology, de-extinction efforts, and xenotransplantation.
timeline: Born in MacDill Air Force Base, Florida
Developed first direct genomic sequencing method
Contributed to Human Genome Project launch
Advanced de-extinction and gene drive research

name: Sumio Iijima
summary: Sumio Iijima is a Japanese physicist who discovered carbon nanotubes in 1991 while studying carbon soot with electron microscopy at NEC Corporation. His discovery launched the field of nanotechnology and opened possibilities for ultra-strong materials, nanoelectronics, and drug delivery systems. Carbon nanotubes are one of the most important materials in nanotechnology.
timeline: Observed carbon onions with electron microscopy

name: Chad Mirkin
summary: Chad Mirkin is an American chemist who invented spherical nucleic acids (SNAs) and dip-pen nanolithography, two foundational technologies in nanotechnology. SNAs have transformed diagnostics and therapeutics, while dip-pen nanolithography enables writing at the nanoscale. He holds over 1,100 patents and is one of the most cited chemists in the world.

name: Robert Langer
summary: Robert Langer is an American chemical engineer who pioneered controlled drug delivery systems and tissue engineering. He developed polymeric nanoparticles for sustained drug release, which transformed how drugs are administered. He holds over 1,400 patents, has co-founded over 40 companies including Moderna, and is the most cited engineer in history.
timeline: Joined Judah Folkman's lab, developed polymer drug delivery
Received Queen Elizabeth Prize for Engineering

name: Xiaowei Zhuang
summary: Xiaowei Zhuang is a Chinese-American biophysicist who invented STORM (Stochastic Optical Reconstruction Microscopy), a super-resolution fluorescence microscopy technique that breaks the optical diffraction limit. She also developed MERFISH, a method for spatially mapping gene expression in tissues, revolutionizing our understanding of tissue organization.

name: Jennifer Doudna
summary: Jennifer Doudna is an American biochemist who co-discovered that the CRISPR-Cas9 bacterial immune system could be reprogrammed to edit DNA. She shared the 2020 Nobel Prize in Chemistry with Emmanuelle Charpentier for developing this revolutionary genome editing tool. CRISPR has transformed biology, medicine, and agriculture.
timeline: Began collaborating with Charpentier on CRISPR
Co-founded Caribou Biosciences and Mammoth Biosciences

name: Emmanuelle Charpentier
summary: Emmanuelle Charpentier is a French microbiologist who co-discovered tracrRNA's role in CRISPR-Cas9 bacterial immune system and co-developed it as a genome editing tool with Jennifer Doudna. She shared the 2020 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. Her discovery of the dual-RNA mechanism was the key insight that enabled programmable gene editing.
timeline: Became director at Max Planck Institute, Berlin

name: Demis Hassabis
summary: Demis Hassabis is a British AI researcher and neuroscientist who co-founded DeepMind. Under his leadership, DeepMind developed AlphaGo (which defeated world Go champion Lee Sedol), AlphaFold (which solved the protein folding problem), and other AI breakthroughs. He shared the 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for AlphaFold's protein structure predictions.
timeline: Earned PhD in cognitive neuroscience from UCL

name: John Jumper
summary: John Jumper is an American AI researcher at DeepMind who led the development of AlphaFold2, which solved the protein structure prediction problem that had challenged biology for 50 years. AlphaFold2 can predict protein structures with atomic accuracy, transforming structural biology and drug discovery. He shared the 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Chicago

name: Yoshua Bengio
summary: Yoshua Bengio is a Canadian computer scientist who is one of the pioneers of deep learning. His work on neural network architectures, generative adversarial networks (GANs), and attention mechanisms helped create the AI revolution. He shared the 2018 Turing Award with Geoffrey Hinton and Yann LeCun for their contributions to deep learning.
timeline: Published seminal work on neural language models
Contributed to attention mechanism and transformer research

name: Yann LeCun
summary: Yann LeCun is a French-American computer scientist who invented convolutional neural networks (CNNs), which became the foundation of modern computer vision and image recognition. His LeNet architecture for handwriting recognition pioneered deep learning. He shared the 2018 Turing Award and serves as Meta's Chief AI Scientist.
timeline: Earned PhD from Université Pierre et Marie Curie
Joined Bell Labs, developed CNN architecture
Became Director of Facebook AI Research

name: Geoffrey Hinton
summary: Geoffrey Hinton is a British-Canadian computer scientist known as the 'Godfather of AI.' He pioneered backpropagation for training neural networks, Boltzmann machines, and deep learning techniques. His work on deep neural networks revolutionized AI. He shared the 2018 Turing Award and the 2024 Nobel Prize in Physics for foundational machine learning discoveries.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Edinburgh
Coined 'deep learning,' demonstrated deep belief networks

name: John Hopfield
summary: John Hopfield is an American physicist who invented the Hopfield network in 1982, an associative memory neural network that could store and retrieve patterns. His work bridging physics and neuroscience laid theoretical foundations for modern neural networks and machine learning. He shared the 2024 Nobel Prize in Physics for foundational work in machine learning.

name: Fei-Fei Li
summary: Fei-Fei Li is a Chinese-American computer scientist who created ImageNet, the massive visual dataset that catalyzed the deep learning revolution in computer vision. The ImageNet Large Scale Visual Recognition Challenge spurred breakthroughs in neural networks. She also served as Chief Scientist of AI at Google Cloud and co-founded Stanford's Human-Centered AI Institute.
timeline: ImageNet challenge won by deep learning (AlexNet)
Served as Chief Scientist of Google Cloud AI

name: Andrew Ng
summary: Andrew Ng is a British-American computer scientist who co-founded Google Brain and was chief scientist at Baidu. He is one of the most influential figures in making AI accessible through Coursera (which he co-founded) and deeplearning.ai. His online machine learning course has been taken by millions and democratized AI education worldwide.
timeline: Founded Google Brain deep learning project

name: Peter Shor
summary: Peter Shor is an American mathematician who developed Shor's algorithm in 1994, a quantum computer algorithm that can factor large integers exponentially faster than classical computers. This discovery showed that quantum computers could break RSA encryption, spurring massive investment in quantum computing and post-quantum cryptography.
timeline: Discovered Shor's algorithm for quantum factoring
Continued quantum computing and information research

name: John Preskill
summary: John Preskill is an American theoretical physicist who coined the term 'quantum supremacy' and has been a leading figure in quantum information science. He directs Caltech's Institute for Quantum Information and Matter. His work on quantum error correction and quantum computing theory has shaped the field's development.
timeline: Coined the term 'quantum computing' era concepts
Founded Caltech Institute for Quantum Information
Introduced concept of NISQ (Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum)

name: Mildred Dresselhaus
summary: Mildred Dresselhaus was an American physicist known as the 'Queen of Carbon Science' for her groundbreaking research on carbon nanostructures. She pioneered the study of carbon nanotubes, graphene, and fullerenes, and her work on thermoelectric materials opened new approaches to energy conversion. She was the first woman to receive the National Medal of Science in Engineering.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Chicago
Served as president of American Physical Society

name: Carolyn Bertozzi
summary: Carolyn Bertozzi is an American chemist who developed bioorthogonal chemistry — chemical reactions that can occur inside living organisms without interfering with biological processes. She shared the 2022 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for this work. Her click chemistry tools enable scientists to study and modify biomolecules in living cells, with applications in drug development and diagnostics.
timeline: Demonstrated bioorthogonal reactions in living animals

name: Frances Arnold
summary: Frances Arnold is an American chemical engineer who pioneered directed evolution of enzymes, a method for engineering proteins by mimicking natural selection in the laboratory. She won the 2018 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for this work. Her evolved enzymes are used in manufacturing pharmaceuticals, biofuels, and agricultural chemicals more sustainably.
timeline: Performed first directed evolution of an enzyme
Applied directed evolution to industrial catalysis

name: Svante Paabo
summary: Svante Pääbo is a Swedish geneticist who founded the field of paleogenomics by sequencing the Neanderthal genome. His work revealed that modern humans interbred with Neanderthals and discovered the Denisovans, a previously unknown hominin species. He won the 2022 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his discoveries on human evolution.
timeline: First to extract DNA from ancient mummies
Founded Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology
Discovered Denisovans from finger bone DNA
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: He Jiankui
summary: He Jiankui is a Chinese biophysicist who created the world's first gene-edited babies in 2018, using CRISPR-Cas9 to modify the CCR5 gene in twin embryos in an attempt to confer HIV resistance. His experiment sparked a global ethical firestorm and he was sentenced to three years in prison. The incident reshaped international discussion on human germline editing.
timeline: Joined Southern University of Science and Technology
Announced birth of CRISPR-edited twin girls
Sentenced to three years in prison

name: Moungi Bawendi
summary: Moungi Bawendi is a French-Tunisian-American chemist who won the 2023 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for the development of quantum dots. He invented the method for producing nearly perfect nanocrystal quantum dots with precisely controlled sizes and optical properties. Quantum dots are used in QLED displays, medical imaging, and solar cells.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Chicago
Developed hot-injection method for quantum dot synthesis
Quantum dots used in commercial displays

name: Alexei Ekimov
summary: Alexei Ekimov is a Russian-American physicist who was the first to discover quantum dots in a glass matrix in 1981, demonstrating size-dependent quantum effects in semiconductor nanocrystals. His discovery that nanoparticle properties change with size launched the field of quantum dot research. He shared the 2023 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.
timeline: Earned PhD from Ioffe Physical-Technical Institute
Published theory of quantum confinement in nanocrystals

name: Louis Brus
summary: Louis Brus is an American chemist who independently discovered colloidal quantum dots in solution and demonstrated quantum size effects in semiconductor nanocrystals. Working at Bell Labs, he developed the theoretical framework for understanding quantum confinement in nanoparticles. He shared the 2023 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for quantum dot research.
timeline: Discovered quantum size effects in colloidal nanocrystals
Developed theory of quantum confinement in solution

name: Yi Xie
summary: Yi Xie is a Chinese inorganic chemist who made pioneering contributions to the synthesis of two-dimensional nanomaterials and their applications in energy conversion and catalysis. She developed novel methods for creating ultrathin nanosheets and defect engineering in nanomaterials. She was the youngest female member elected to the Chinese Academy of Sciences.
timeline: Elected to Chinese Academy of Sciences

name: Norman Borlaug
summary: Norman Borlaug was an American agronomist known as the 'Father of the Green Revolution.' He developed high-yielding, disease-resistant wheat varieties that saved an estimated one billion people from starvation in developing countries. He won the 1970 Nobel Peace Prize. His semi-dwarf wheat varieties transformed agriculture in Mexico, India, and Pakistan.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Minnesota
High-yield wheat adopted in India and Pakistan

name: M. S. Swaminathan
summary: M. S. Swaminathan was an Indian agricultural scientist known as the 'Father of the Indian Green Revolution.' He introduced and adapted Norman Borlaug's high-yielding wheat varieties to Indian conditions, transforming India from a food-deficit nation to a food-sufficient one. His work saved hundreds of millions from famine.
timeline: Born in Kumbakonam, Tamil Nadu, India
Introduced high-yielding wheat varieties in India
India achieved food self-sufficiency in wheat

name: Gurdev Singh Khush
summary: Gurdev Singh Khush is an Indian-American plant geneticist who developed over 300 rice varieties at the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI), including IR36 and IR64 — the most widely planted rice varieties in history. His high-yielding, disease-resistant rice varieties helped feed billions of people in Asia and contributed to the Green Revolution.

name: Monkombu Sambasivan Swaminathan
summary: Duplicate entry - see M. S. Swaminathan.

name: Ingo Potrykus
summary: Ingo Potrykus is a German-Swiss plant scientist who co-invented Golden Rice, a genetically modified rice variety enriched with beta-carotene (provitamin A). Golden Rice was developed to combat vitamin A deficiency, which causes blindness and death in hundreds of thousands of children annually. The project sparked a major debate on GMO crop policy.
timeline: Earned PhD from Max Planck Institute
Began Golden Rice development with Peter Beyer
Published Golden Rice creation in Science
Golden Rice approved in the Philippines

name: Peter Beyer
summary: Peter Beyer is a German cell biologist who co-invented Golden Rice with Ingo Potrykus. He engineered the metabolic pathway to produce beta-carotene in rice endosperm and later developed improved versions with higher carotenoid content. His work aimed to address vitamin A deficiency affecting 250 million children in developing countries.
timeline: Began Golden Rice collaboration with Potrykus
Developed Golden Rice 2 with 23x more beta-carotene

name: Pamela Ronald
summary: Pamela Ronald is an American plant pathologist who discovered the rice Xa21 gene conferring broad-spectrum disease resistance. Her research has been central to developing disease-resistant rice varieties using genetic engineering. She advocates for sustainable agriculture combining genetic engineering with organic farming practices.
timeline: Cloned the Xa21 rice disease resistance gene
Received USDA National Research Initiative award

name: Robert Fraley
summary: Robert Fraley is an American biochemist who led the development of the first genetically modified crops at Monsanto. He developed the techniques for inserting genes into plant cells, enabling the creation of Roundup Ready soybeans and Bt corn. He shared the 2013 World Food Prize for his contributions to agricultural biotechnology.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of California

name: Jocelyn Bell Burnell
summary: Jocelyn Bell Burnell is a British astrophysicist who discovered pulsars in 1967 as a graduate student at Cambridge, one of the most important astronomical discoveries of the 20th century. Controversially, the 1974 Nobel Prize for this discovery was awarded to her supervisor Antony Hewish instead. She has been widely recognized as having been unjustly overlooked by the Nobel committee.
timeline: Entered Cambridge University as graduate student
Nobel Prize awarded to Hewish and Ryle (not Burnell)
Awarded Breakthrough Prize in Physics ($3 million)

name: Chien-Shiung Wu
summary: Chien-Shiung Wu was a Chinese-American physicist who experimentally proved parity violation in weak interactions in 1957. Known as the 'First Lady of Physics,' her Wu experiment was one of the most important experiments in particle physics. Despite her Nobel-caliber contribution, she was controversially not included in the 1957 Nobel Prize awarded to Lee and Yang.
timeline: Became first female president of American Physical Society

name: Barbara McClintock
summary: Barbara McClintock was an American geneticist who discovered transposable elements ('jumping genes') in corn in the 1940s. Her work was initially dismissed but eventually recognized as a fundamental mechanism of genetic regulation. She won the 1983 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, one of the few scientists to win an unshared Nobel.
timeline: Published cytogenetic map of corn chromosomes
Elected to National Academy of Sciences
Presented transposition at Cold Spring Harbor
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Rosalind Franklin
summary: Rosalind Franklin was a British chemist whose X-ray diffraction image 'Photo 51' was crucial for determining the double helix structure of DNA. Her data, shared without her knowledge, was used by Watson and Crick in their DNA model. She also made important contributions to understanding coal, graphite, and virus structures. She died of cancer at age 37.
timeline: Joined King's College London, began DNA research
Produced Photo 51, the key DNA diffraction image
Watson and Crick published DNA structure using her data
Began virus structure research at Birkbeck College
Died of ovarian cancer in London

name: Mae Jemison
summary: Mae Jemison is an American physician and NASA astronaut who became the first African-American woman to travel to space, aboard the Space Shuttle Endeavour in 1992. She served as a Peace Corps medical officer in Sierra Leone and Liberia before being selected by NASA. After leaving NASA, she founded a technology company and education programs.
timeline: Served as Peace Corps physician in West Africa
Selected by NASA for astronaut program
Flew on STS-47 Endeavour, first Black woman in space
Resigned from NASA, founded technology company

name: Katherine Johnson
summary: Katherine Johnson was an American mathematician whose orbital mechanics calculations at NASA were critical for the success of the first U.S. crewed spaceflights. She calculated the trajectory for Alan Shepard's Mercury flight, verified the orbital equations for John Glenn's mission, and computed trajectories for Apollo 11. Her story was told in 'Hidden Figures.'
timeline: Born in White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia
Graduated from West Virginia State College
Calculated trajectory for Alan Shepard's flight

name: Lise Meitner
summary: Lise Meitner was an Austrian-Swedish physicist who, with her nephew Otto Frisch, provided the first theoretical explanation of nuclear fission in 1939. Despite her crucial contribution, she was excluded from the Nobel Prize awarded to her collaborator Otto Hahn. Einstein called her 'the German Marie Curie.' Element 109, meitnerium, is named after her.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Vienna
Began 30-year collaboration with Otto Hahn in Berlin
Explained nuclear fission with Otto Frisch
Nobel Prize given to Hahn alone

name: Valentina Tereshkova
summary: Valentina Tereshkova was the first woman to travel to space, orbiting Earth 48 times aboard Vostok 6 in June 1963. A textile worker and amateur parachutist, she was selected from over 400 applicants for the Soviet space program. Her flight lasted nearly three days, during which she conducted scientific experiments and took photographs of Earth's atmosphere.
timeline: Flew Vostok 6, first woman in space
Named greatest woman of the 20th century

name: Sally Ride
summary: Sally Ride was an American physicist and astronaut who became the first American woman in space aboard the Space Shuttle Challenger in 1983. She flew two shuttle missions and later served on the investigation boards for both the Challenger and Columbia disasters. She founded Sally Ride Science to inspire young women in STEM fields.

name: Marie Tharp
summary: Marie Tharp was an American geologist who created the first comprehensive map of the ocean floor, revealing the mid-ocean ridge system and providing crucial evidence for the theory of plate tectonics. Her maps transformed our understanding of Earth's geology. She identified the rift valley running along the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, supporting continental drift theory.
timeline: Joined Columbia University's Lamont Geological Observatory
Began mapping ocean floor with Bruce Heezen
Published first physiographic maps of North Atlantic floor
Published comprehensive World Ocean Floor Panorama

name: Inge Lehmann
summary: Inge Lehmann was a Danish seismologist who discovered Earth's solid inner core in 1936 by analyzing seismic waves from earthquakes. Before her discovery, scientists believed the entire core was liquid. She showed that P-waves reflected off a boundary within the core, proving the existence of a solid inner core. She lived to be 104 years old.
timeline: Became head of Danish seismological department
Identified the Lehmann discontinuity in the upper mantle

name: Eunice Newton Foote
summary: Eunice Newton Foote was an American scientist who was the first person to document the greenhouse effect of carbon dioxide in 1856, three years before John Tyndall's better-known experiments. She demonstrated that CO2 and water vapor absorb heat and proposed that changes in atmospheric CO2 could change climate. Her contribution was overlooked for over 150 years.
timeline: Attended Seneca Falls women's rights convention
Published paper on greenhouse effect of CO2

name: Sylvia Earle
summary: Sylvia Earle is an American marine biologist and explorer known as 'Her Deepness.' She led the first all-female team of aquanauts, set a women's depth record for solo diving, and served as NOAA's first female chief scientist. She founded Mission Blue to establish Hope Spots — marine protected areas. She has logged over 7,000 hours underwater.
timeline: Led Tektite II all-female aquanaut team
Set solo dive depth record of 1,250 feet
Became first female NOAA chief scientist
Founded Mission Blue ocean conservation initiative

name: Wally Funk
summary: Wally Funk is an American aviator who was one of the Mercury 13, a group of women who passed NASA astronaut qualification tests in the early 1960s but were denied the opportunity to fly because of their gender. She finally flew to space on July 20, 2021, aboard Blue Origin's New Shepard, at age 82, becoming the oldest person to fly to space at that time.
timeline: Born in Las Vegas, New Mexico
Became first female NTSB air safety investigator
Flew to space on Blue Origin NS-16 at age 82

name: Wang Zhenyi
summary: Wang Zhenyi was a Qing Dynasty woman astronomer and mathematician who conducted experiments explaining lunar eclipses and wrote on mathematics, astronomy, and poetry. In an era when women were denied education, she self-taught astronomy and demonstrated eclipse mechanics using a round table, lamp, and mirror. She died at only 29 but left a significant scientific legacy.
timeline: Born in Anhui, Qing Dynasty China
Published mathematical works on Pythagorean theorem

name: Nettie Stevens
summary: Nettie Stevens was an American geneticist who discovered that sex is determined by X and Y chromosomes in 1905, studying mealworm beetles. Her discovery was one of the most important in genetics. Despite publishing her findings simultaneously with Edmund Beecher Wilson, he received most of the credit during her lifetime due to gender bias.
timeline: Earned PhD from Bryn Mawr College
Discovered XY sex determination in mealworms
Published additional papers on chromosomal inheritance
Died of breast cancer at age 50

name: Emmy Noether
summary: Emmy Noether was a German mathematician who made groundbreaking contributions to abstract algebra and theoretical physics. Noether's theorem, which proves that every symmetry in physics corresponds to a conservation law, is one of the most important theorems in physics. Einstein called her the most important woman in the history of mathematics.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Erlangen
Fled Nazi Germany to United States

name: Mary Anning
summary: Mary Anning was a British fossil collector and paleontologist who made some of the most important fossil discoveries in history along the Jurassic Coast. She discovered the first correctly identified Ichthyosaur skeleton, the first nearly complete Plesiosaurus, and the first British Pterodactylus. Despite her contributions, she was largely excluded from the scientific establishment due to her gender and class.
timeline: Born in Lyme Regis, Dorset, England
Found first British example of fossil cuttlefish ink
Died of breast cancer in Lyme Regis

name: Ignaz Semmelweis
summary: Ignaz Semmelweis was a Hungarian physician who discovered that hand washing with chlorinated lime solutions dramatically reduced puerperal fever (childbed fever) mortality in maternity clinics. Despite clear evidence, his ideas were rejected by the medical establishment. He suffered a breakdown and died in an asylum. He is now recognized as the pioneer of antiseptic procedures.
timeline: Earned medical degree from University of Vienna
Published 'Etiology, Concept and Prophylaxis of Childbed Fever'
Died in Vienna, likely beaten by asylum guards

name: Joseph Lister
summary: Joseph Lister was a British surgeon who pioneered antiseptic surgery using carbolic acid (phenol) to sterilize surgical instruments and clean wounds. Before Lister, surgical mortality from infection was extremely high. His antiseptic techniques, introduced in the 1860s, dramatically reduced post-operative deaths and transformed surgery into a relatively safe procedure.
timeline: Earned medical degree from University College London
Became professor of surgery at Glasgow
Published 'Antiseptic Principle of the Practice of Surgery'
Moved to King's College Hospital, London

name: Crawford Long
summary: Crawford Long was an American physician who was the first to use diethyl ether as a surgical anesthetic in 1842, removing a neck tumor from a patient painlessly. He did not publish his results until 1849, after William Morton's public demonstration in 1846. The debate over who deserves credit for discovering anesthesia continues, but Long's operation preceded all others.
timeline: Earned medical degree from University of Pennsylvania
First used ether anesthesia during surgery
Morton publicly demonstrated ether at Massachusetts General
Published account of his 1842 use of ether

name: Edward Jenner
summary: Edward Jenner was an English physician who developed the world's first vaccine in 1796, using cowpox material to create immunity against smallpox. His discovery that milkmaids who had caught cowpox were immune to smallpox led to the practice of vaccination. His work eventually led to the complete eradication of smallpox in 1980, the greatest achievement in public health history.
timeline: Vaccinated James Phipps with cowpox material
Published 'An Inquiry into the Causes and Effects of the Variolae Vaccinae'

name: John Snow
summary: John Snow was an English physician considered the father of modern epidemiology. He traced the 1854 Broad Street cholera outbreak in London to a contaminated water pump, demonstrating that cholera is waterborne rather than airborne. His removal of the pump handle is one of the most famous events in public health history. He also pioneered the use of anesthesia.
timeline: Published 'On the Mode of Communication of Cholera'
Administered chloroform to Queen Victoria during childbirth
Traced Broad Street cholera outbreak to water pump
Published second edition with detailed epidemiological maps

name: Paul Ehrlich
summary: Paul Ehrlich was a German physician who developed the first effective treatment for syphilis (Salvarsan, compound 606), pioneered chemotherapy, and made foundational contributions to immunology. He proposed the side-chain theory of immunity and developed staining techniques for blood cells. He shared the 1908 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.
timeline: Developed staining technique for tuberculosis bacillus
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
Salvarsan became most prescribed drug in the world

name: Yuri Gagarin
summary: Yuri Gagarin was a Soviet cosmonaut who became the first human to travel into outer space on April 12, 1961, aboard Vostok 1. His single orbit of Earth lasted 108 minutes and made him an international hero and a symbol of the Space Age. His flight demonstrated that humans could survive in space and catalyzed the space race.
timeline: First human in space aboard Vostok 1 (April 12)
Became international celebrity and goodwill ambassador
Died in MiG-15 training jet crash

name: Alan Shepard
summary: Alan Shepard was an American astronaut who became the first American in space on May 5, 1961, during a 15-minute suborbital flight aboard Freedom 7. He later commanded Apollo 14 in 1971, becoming the fifth person to walk on the Moon and famously hitting golf balls on the lunar surface. He was one of the original Mercury Seven astronauts.
timeline: Selected as one of Mercury Seven astronauts
Grounded due to inner ear problem
Hit golf balls on the Moon

name: Wernher von Braun
summary: Wernher von Braun was a German-American aerospace engineer who was the chief architect of the Saturn V rocket that carried astronauts to the Moon. He developed the V-2 rocket for Nazi Germany during WWII, then came to the US under Operation Paperclip. At NASA, he led the development of the rockets that made the Apollo Moon landings possible.
timeline: Earned PhD in physics from University of Berlin
Surrendered to Americans, brought to US
Became director of NASA Marshall Space Flight Center
Saturn V launched Apollo 11 to the Moon

name: Sergei Korolev
summary: Sergei Korolev was the chief rocket engineer and spacecraft designer of the Soviet space program, responsible for Sputnik, the first artificial satellite, and Vostok, the spacecraft that carried Yuri Gagarin into space. His identity was kept secret during his lifetime, known only as 'Chief Designer.' He is considered the founder of practical astronautics.
timeline: Born in Zhytomyr, Russian Empire (now Ukraine)
Arrested during Stalin's purges, sent to gulag
Launched Yuri Gagarin into space on Vostok 1

name: Kalpana Chawla
summary: Kalpana Chawla was an Indian-American astronaut and aerospace engineer who was the first woman of Indian origin to go to space. She flew on the Space Shuttle Columbia twice, first in 1997 and again in 2003. She died when Columbia disintegrated during re-entry on February 1, 2003, along with six other crew members.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Colorado
Died in Columbia disaster during re-entry

name: Yang Liwei
summary: Yang Liwei is a Chinese astronaut who became the first Chinese person in space aboard Shenzhou 5 on October 15, 2003. His 21-hour flight made China the third country (after Russia and the US) to independently send a human into space. He became a national hero and later served as deputy director of China's manned space program.
timeline: Joined People's Liberation Army Air Force
First Chinese person in space aboard Shenzhou 5
Appointed deputy director of China Manned Space Agency

name: Peggy Whitson
summary: Peggy Whitson is an American astronaut and biochemist who holds the record for the most time in space by any American astronaut and any woman worldwide (over 665 days). She was the first woman to command the International Space Station and the oldest woman to fly in space. She completed 10 spacewalks during her career.
timeline: Earned PhD in biochemistry from Rice University

name: Liu Yang
summary: Liu Yang is a Chinese astronaut who became the first Chinese woman to travel to space aboard Shenzhou 9 in June 2012. A military transport pilot, she was selected for the astronaut program in 2010. She also flew on Shenzhou 14 in 2022, serving as part of the crew that completed the Tiangong space station.
timeline: Joined People's Liberation Army Air Force
First Chinese woman in space aboard Shenzhou 9
Flew Shenzhou 14 to Tiangong space station

name: Soichi Noguchi
summary: Soichi Noguchi is a Japanese astronaut who has flown three different spacecraft types: the Space Shuttle (2005), Soyuz (2009-2010), and SpaceX Crew Dragon (2020). He performed three spacewalks during STS-114, the first shuttle flight after the Columbia disaster, and spent 163 days aboard the ISS. He is one of JAXA's most experienced astronauts.
timeline: Flew STS-114, first post-Columbia shuttle mission
Flew to ISS on SpaceX Crew Dragon (Crew-1)

name: Robert Goddard
summary: Robert Goddard was an American physicist and engineer who built and launched the world's first liquid-fueled rocket on March 16, 1926. He is considered the father of modern rocketry. He held 214 patents and developed innovations including gyroscopic stabilization and payload compartments. His work, initially ridiculed, was vindicated by the Space Age.
timeline: Published 'A Method of Reaching Extreme Altitudes'
Moved to Roswell, New Mexico for testing
Launched rocket exceeding speed of sound

name: Konstantin Tsiolkovsky
summary: Konstantin Tsiolkovsky was a Russian rocket scientist who is considered the founding father of astronautics. He derived the Tsiolkovsky rocket equation, proposed multi-stage rockets, space stations, and spacesuits. Despite being nearly deaf and self-educated, he mathematically proved that rockets could achieve spaceflight and proposed liquid hydrogen and oxygen as optimal propellants.
timeline: Published 'Exploration of Outer Space by Means of Rocket Devices'

name: Charles Richter
summary: Charles Richter was an American seismologist who developed the Richter magnitude scale in 1935, the standard measure of earthquake size used worldwide. Created at Caltech with Beno Gutenberg, the logarithmic scale provided the first quantitative measure of earthquake magnitude. Though largely replaced by the moment magnitude scale, his name remains synonymous with earthquake measurement.
timeline: Developed Richter magnitude scale with Gutenberg
Published 'Seismicity of the Earth' with Gutenberg

name: Alfred Wegener
summary: Alfred Wegener was a German meteorologist and geophysicist who proposed the theory of continental drift in 1912, suggesting that continents were once joined as a supercontinent (Pangaea) and have since drifted apart. His theory was ridiculed during his lifetime but was vindicated in the 1960s when plate tectonics was established. He died during a Greenland expedition.
timeline: Published 'The Origin of Continents and Oceans'
Fourth edition of his book with more evidence

name: Harry Hess
summary: Harry Hess was an American geologist who proposed the theory of seafloor spreading in 1962, providing the mechanism for continental drift and laying the foundation for the theory of plate tectonics. Using sonar data from his WWII naval service, he discovered that the ocean floor was being created at mid-ocean ridges and consumed at ocean trenches.
timeline: Served in US Navy, collected sonar data

name: Charles David Keeling
summary: Charles David Keeling was an American geochemist who began the first continuous measurements of atmospheric carbon dioxide at Mauna Loa Observatory in 1958. The resulting Keeling Curve, showing the steady rise of CO2, became one of the most important scientific datasets in history and a cornerstone of climate change science.
timeline: Began CO2 measurements at Mauna Loa, Hawaii

name: James Hansen
summary: James Hansen is an American climatologist who is often called the 'father of climate change awareness.' As director of NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies, his 1988 testimony to the US Congress brought global warming to worldwide public attention. His climate models accurately predicted global temperature trends and he became an outspoken advocate for climate action.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Iowa
Testified to Congress on global warming
His testimony made front-page news worldwide
Retired from NASA, continued climate activism

name: Jacques Cousteau
summary: Jacques Cousteau was a French oceanographer and explorer who co-invented the Aqua-Lung (modern scuba diving regulator) and pioneered marine conservation. His ship Calypso and his television series The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau brought ocean exploration into millions of homes worldwide. He founded the Cousteau Society for marine conservation.
timeline: Won Palme d'Or for 'The Silent World'

name: Alexander von Humboldt
summary: Alexander von Humboldt was a German naturalist and explorer whose five-year expedition to the Americas (1799-1804) produced the most comprehensive scientific description of any part of the world up to that time. He is considered the father of ecology and biogeography, and his concept of nature as an interconnected web anticipated modern environmental science.
timeline: Began five-year expedition to the Americas

name: Rachel Carson
summary: Rachel Carson was an American marine biologist and writer whose book Silent Spring (1962) documented the devastating effects of pesticides on the environment and human health. Her work led to the ban of DDT and inspired the modern environmental movement. She is credited with launching the environmental awareness that led to the creation of the EPA.
timeline: Earned master's from Johns Hopkins University
Testified before Congress on pesticide dangers
Died of breast cancer in Silver Spring, Maryland

name: Pieter Zeeman
summary: Pieter Zeeman was a Dutch physicist who discovered the Zeeman effect — the splitting of spectral lines in a magnetic field. This discovery provided crucial evidence for the electron theory of Hendrik Lorentz and was important for understanding atomic structure. He shared the 1902 Nobel Prize in Physics with Lorentz.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Leiden
Became professor at University of Amsterdam

name: Milutin Milankovic
summary: Milutin Milanković was a Serbian mathematician and astronomer who developed the theory of Milankovitch cycles, which explains how variations in Earth's orbit (eccentricity, obliquity, and precession) cause ice ages and long-term climate change. His mathematical model, initially dismissed, was confirmed by deep-sea sediment studies in the 1970s and is now fundamental to climate science.
timeline: Born in Dalj, Austro-Hungarian Empire (now Croatia)
Earned PhD from Vienna Institute of Technology
Became professor at University of Belgrade
Began calculating solar radiation and ice ages
Published theory of insolation and ice ages
Published 'Canon of Insolation of the Earth'

name: Andrija Mohorovicic
summary: Andrija Mohorovičić was a Croatian meteorologist and seismologist who discovered the Mohorovičić discontinuity (Moho), the boundary between Earth's crust and mantle. In 1909, analyzing seismic waves from a Croatian earthquake, he identified the velocity change that marks this boundary. The Moho is one of the most fundamental features of Earth's internal structure.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Prague
Became head of Croatian Meteorological Observatory

name: Bruce Heezen
summary: Bruce Heezen was an American geologist who, together with Marie Tharp, created the first comprehensive maps of the ocean floor. Their work revealed the global mid-ocean ridge system and rift valleys, providing key evidence for seafloor spreading and plate tectonics. He died of a heart attack in a submarine while surveying the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.
timeline: Began mapping ocean floor with Marie Tharp at Lamont
Published first North Atlantic floor map
Discovered turbidity currents' role in undersea geology
Died in submarine off Reykjanes Ridge, Iceland

name: Yi So-yeon
summary: Yi So-yeon is a South Korean astronaut who became the first Korean to fly in space aboard Soyuz TMA-12 to the International Space Station in April 2008. She spent 11 days on the ISS conducting 18 scientific experiments. A biosystems engineer, she later earned an MBA and worked in science policy and education.
timeline: Graduated from KAIST in biosystems engineering
Flew to ISS aboard Soyuz TMA-12
Earned MBA from Haas School of Business, UC Berkeley

name: Chiaki Mukai
summary: Chiaki Mukai is a Japanese physician and astronaut who became the first Japanese woman to fly in space aboard STS-65 in 1994. She flew again on STS-95 in 1998 alongside John Glenn. A cardiovascular surgeon, she conducted medical experiments in microgravity and later served as an executive at JAXA.
timeline: Graduated from Keio University School of Medicine
